reviewText: This movie is not a comedy.  It's not actually even a good script.  It's well-written but the whole basis of the script:  marriage, affair, pathetic and sad.It is saved by the phenomenal acting of two of the greatest actors of the century.  But the script says, "Hollywood is desperate for decent scripts."
Title: N/A

reviewText: Nora Ephron famously wrote this book and movie adaptation after her husband Carl Bernstein chested on her.  I just read the Jack Nicholson biography in which Bob comes to him before he takes the part of the philandering husband.  Bob begs him not to take the part.  This little factoid impelled me to watch this wonderful movie again.Of course, after a court case,the names and professions were changed, but this doesn't do much to hide the story.  The movie stands alone as a wry, witty account of a woman floundering to save her marriage.  The writing is brilliant.  Meryl Streep is understated in a lovely role.  Jack Nicholson plays his role with the famous "Jack" signature devilish smile and mobile eyebrows.  The emotions run true and i feel it has always been underrated as a movie.
summary: Revenge is a dish best served cold.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I saw 'Heartburn' for the first time in a long time last night on HBO.  The movie itself - well, time has naturally disassociated it somewhat with the book, so my disappointment at the bleached-out film version of Ephron's tale (WASP-ified, cooking elements in very deep background) has faded away.Now, the story stands on its own, especially thanks to Streep's strong performance & the excellent Carly Simon music (especially the "Itsy-Bitsy Spider" tie-in).  The last 15 minutes or so - really great stuff.  The 'key lime pie in the face' scene continues to be a perfect cinematic moment.But here are three new reasons to watch -- "Hey, it's Kevin Spacey!"  What a surprise to see him in what had to have been one of his first screen roles.- Eastern Airlines shots.  That brings back a lot of memories for anyone who took the Shuttle on a regular basis.- Processing Meryl Streep's credit card *on the plane* with a old card imprinter.  Wow!  How times have changed.

reviewText: I read the book when it first was published, and it was great, but I just watched the movie yesterday and did enjoy it, just not as much as the book. Ephron is a clever writer in any medium. Streep did a wonderful job and it was so good to see her as such a "young" age. Nicholson has not changed all that much.It was a story that the talented cast and writers managed to imbue with some humor and a lot of pathos. Some scenes were too heavy handed, like the one before the wedding when Rachel was in the bedroom agonizing (the scene seemed to go on FOREVER). I did not see much of a spark between Streep and Nicholson...that casting could have been better.But overall, it was worth watching.

reviewText: When Nora Ephron died, I saw this movie to pay my respects! The movie is utterly entertaining, with great dialogue and fantastic performances.

reviewText: A slow, loggy movie about a philandering husband (everyone was guessing this was Watergate reporter Carl Bernstein in the Nora Ephron novel on which the movie is based; he was Ephron's husband). Jack Nicholson plays the husband and Meryl Streep the wife, and both are uncharacteristically bland. There is hardly anything to the story: they marry, she gets pregnant, he gets restless and wanders. We finish watching knowing and caring as little about all this as when we started. Very dull.
summary: Heartburn is the least of the ills caused by this movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: Other than as Nora Ephron's vengeance against the philandering Carl Bernstein, this movie makes absolutely no sense. There is no plot, per se. They get married, he cheats, they break up. So? If this is supposed to be a comedy, it's not funny. Nicholson is wasted, and so is Meryl Streep. Critics savaged this when it came out. They were correct.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie should go into the Hall of Shame, as it has one of the better casts ever in a movie, and is still almost unwatchable.  In particular, when a writer creates a screenplay that threatens to take down the greatest actress of our generation (maybe ever) - Meryl Streep - then the writer deserves more than a Razzie.But it's not just the writer who is at fault.  The soundtrack is absolutely grating.  Now, I myself have always liked Carly Simon over the years, but Ms. Simon has many songs, many of them very good.  Why is it then that she, or those doing post production work, decided to use "Coming Around Again" over and over again, maybe with the original at first, and then variant instrumental versions?  Why not other songs, such as "You're So Vain" for example?  Wouldn't that song have fit the Jack Nicholson character as well?  Let's mix it up a bit here!In this film, Ms. Streep's character is a mess but she's supposed to be.  So, well played once again with what she had to work with.  But the movie feels like a mess as well, little scenes thrown in just because they seemingly have to be in any movie.  Weddings, dinner parties, pity parties, etc.  I would say that if you've just gone through a bad breakup and want to lay around and eat ice cream and cry like a little baby, this film might be just for you.  Otherwise, avoid at all cost.And don't forget to put the Tums on the coffee table while watching.  You're gonna need 'em. . . .
summary: Pick up the remote and grab a Tums

reviewText: Not much depth to this so-called "comedy", despite a well-regarded cast and lovable child actors.  Domestic discord is ostensibly the focus, but it's not treated in a particularly funny fashion. Every so often, we do encounter a visual gag or a snappy one-liner, but there's really not enough oomph or sustained entertainment value to the film.  Probably best to pass on this one.

reviewerName: David Thomson "Second Rate Eric Hoffer Imitator"
reviewText: Nora Ephron wrote the screenplay of this modestly entertaining movie. Was this the best that she could do?  No, I suspect that this project deteriorated into a therapeutic exercise. Ephron preferred to get in touch with her feelings. Writing it to please an audience subconsciously became a secondary goal. Heartburn should be seen only by those interested in the somewhat autobiographical retelling of the failed marriage between Ephron and Carl Bernstein. Everybody else should ignore this movie. Berstein comes across as an untrustworthy cad and Ephron a gullible victim. The acting talents of Jack Nicholson and Meryl Streep save Heartburn. Your life will not end if you never view this film---but it might be worth a few hours of your time. Flip a coin. That may be the best way to make the decision.
summary: Was Nora Ephron Indulging in Screen Writing as Therapy?

reviewText: I avoided this movie when it was released because I couldn't imagine that a film based on the marital breakup of Nora Ephron and Carl Bernstein would interest me. Although I am an admirer of both these folks for their talents as writers, I had always agreed with Richard Burton when he said, when asked if he would be writing about his marriage and breakup with Elizabeth Taylor, that even though love might be dead, that it wasn't for sale. Be that as it may, this movie is certainly worth seeing. Although the plot is a little thin, there are some very funny moments. (Whether some of the events actually happened in the Bernstein/Ephron saga doesn't matter.) Any film directed by Mike Nichols, starring Meryl Streep and Jack Nicholson, with cinematography by Nestor Amendros is well worth seeing.Both Ms. Ephron and the viewer have the last laugh.

This is one of the best all-time yet under-rated movies out there. Any movie lover will adore this quick-wit flick. Stock Channing makes a memorable performance, too.

reviewText: I didn't see this movie when it came out, which is too bad, because I might have liked it a bit in the 80's. But I found it dated, and there was no chemistry between Streep and Nicholson. I normally love Nora Ephron, but her character in this is self-pitying and neurotic (seriously: how else would you describe a 30-something woman who thinks nothing of making her wedding guests...make that second wedding guests...wait for HOURS while she lies on her bed in angst, trying to decide whether to tie the knot with Nicholson). I gather this was supposed to be cute, but Streep's character is not cute, and Nicholson's character is a louse, so there's not a lot to like in either of them. I know I'm in the minority; most women apparently love this movie, which is fine; just don't count me among them.
summary: Heartburn is what I had after watching this movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am absolutely stunned to see what this sells for used even in VHS. I have a copy from years ago and watch it every now and then. Just watched it again and was surprised, again, at how it draws one in. But, maybe you have to be a woman to feel this.  Who else but Jack Nicholson can be so charming and so horrible practically all in the same scene.  Who else would we believe would comfort his wife sweetly while she gives birth to his second child and also believe, at the same time, that he doesn't really give a rat's ass about either the wife or the children. Only Nicholson can pull that one off.  Meryl Streep is perfect as the sophisticated career woman who captivates him then settles boringly into domesticity so completely that she changes herself so much that he doesn't even remember what she was like before. Trust me, never try to either build or totally redecorate a home with a new spouse - even an old spouse. It is a marriage destroyer.  Of course she is so blissfully happy and pregnant that she is clueless and Ms Streep makes this evident without saying a word. And, who else can look so glowingly beautiful one minute and so witch like a minute later. Stockard Channing is unique and I've never understood why she wasn't a bigger star. All of the supporting cast is wonderful.If this story is really based on real life as reported then bless her heart I hope she settled into her well earned success and flipped him off every time she saw him. I enjoy this movie. I think others will too. Well, mostly women. I just noticed in reading the other reviews that all the low ratings are done by men.

reviewText: The movie is a great love story of a husband and wife, Meryl and Jack, who go through the highs and lows of marriage.  Meryl is outstanding as expected and Jack does his usual performance.  I find it interesting that Jack is one of our best male actors and yet you know it is him playing the part in everything he does.  Meryl can change with the role.  Although this part does not allow for her to do a great transformation as she did in Sophie's Choice or Angels in America, she does make you believe that she is in fact this wife who's husband cheats on.  If you love Meryl and/or Jack, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: I will always sing the praises of Meryl Streep. This wonderfully gifted actress is capable of taking any role and infusing it with such passion and dedication that she can make a dull movie like HEARTBURN entertaining, just to bask in the glow of her performance.  Based on Nora Ephron's novel and her marriage to Carl Bernstein, HEARTBURN doesn't really "do" much of anything.  Streep marries philandering Jack Nicholson (in one of his more bland performances), has a couple of kids, and finds out he's cheating on her (duh?).  Ephron's script cripples its stars by making Streep a little too whiny and self-pitying and Nicholson a little too dispassionate and predictable.  One of the true crimes of this movie is Oscar's neglect to praise the movie's showpiece song COMIN AROUND AGAIN.  Carly Simon's song poignantly evokes the loss but hope in any kind of relationship; it's pairing with the old children's ITSY BITSY SPIDER is creative genius.  The spider gets washed down the spout but always goes back up to try again; in COMIN AROUND AGAIN, the song's emphasis on "I believe in love" mirrors the tenacity of the spider.  What a shame Simon wasn't awarded for this feat.  You will like HEARTBURN if you are fans of Streep and Nicholson, but it's not one of their best efforts.

reviewText: This is an unusual film, a lightly plotted rendition of the end of a marriage. The cinematography is interesting, lots of very long takes and surprising camera angles. The wedding vows, for example, are shown from the point of view of the rabbi, and we see the couple's faces in closeup throughout. Some of the scenes are true to life, touching, and better than similar scenes in other films. The childbirth sequences, for example, have no peer I can think of. There are a few funny scenes as well, especially one in which Meryl Streep describes a (fake) embarrassment pertaining to romantic rival to a gossipy friend (excellently played by Catherine O'Hara).The film has problems, though, chief among them that the story is overly simplistic. Streep's character marries a guy who cheats on her. We are given no reason why he cheats. She splits with him, gets back together, and he cheats again, worse even than the first time. No reason is given; Streep's character (a stand-in for author Nora Ephron) is basically a saint. I can see where writing this might have been therapeutic for Ephron, but it's not dramatically interesting.Also, the couple buys a rundown house in Washington DC upon getting married. There is some failed humor as they fix it up, and all looks cleaned up and good before Streep realizes her husband's infidelity. Then, in step with the decay in their marriage, we see the house falling apart too -- rain comes in through the ceiling, and in a late scene we are shown open channels for electrical cables in the walls. Symbolically, the house was never as good as we had thought. Maybe for some this would be smart, but I thought it was too heavy handed.Decent acting by all the main characters; the problem was the script, not the performances.p.s. watch for an amusing early appearance by Kevin Spacey as an urban criminal.
summary: an odd film, much to like but not a success overall

reviewText: One of Nora Ephron's best with excellent performances by Streep and Nickolson. I felt as if I knew these characters like they were my neighbors. The humor is subtly contained within the dialogue; however, it's a drama -first and foremost- about marriage and friendship. It's similar to "When Harry Met Sally," but with a different storyline. Definitely, watch this one.

reviewText: I viewed 'Heartburn' again to commemorate Nora Ephron, the writer. This was a movie of her life and marriage to Carl Bernstein.Nora was ravaged by the critics for this book and film, but time was on her side .Norah always stood up for women and their roles in life. She worked and lived in a man's world. She took the slings and arrows for many of us. This film is a must see about the life of a marriage when one spouse cheats. It is down and dirty and lovely!  Meryl Streep plays Norah's part, and Jack Nicholson plays the part of the husband. He was always a lady's man, and it seems he never stopped. He was a DC journalist and Streep plays the part of a food writer . Jack is not likable, charming, yes, but despicable. He cheats on Meryl while she is pregnant with their second child .  The most amusing part of the film is that Meryl spreads ugly rumors about the woman Jack is cheating with.  Meryl takes Jack back, but as times goes on, she knows he will continue his philandering, and she leaves. She has enough sense of herself to know that she will never be happy, otherwise.Norah Ephron is a woman to be much admired. A true forerunner of the modern woman. Thank you, Norah for what you have given us.Highly Recommended. prisrob 06-27-12I Remember Nothing: and Other ReflectionsI Feel Bad About My Neck: And Other Thoughts on Being a Woman
Title: N/A

reviewText: I confess that I didn't buy this DVD from Amazon.  In a moment of total boredom I found it on Netflix and downloaded it, knowing only that it starred Meryl Streep and Jack Nicholson. I didn't realize until it was over that it was based on the Nora Ephron/Carl Bernstein marriage.  This was an advantage as I had no expectations of what would happen and I didn't have any preconceptions about the characters.  I liked the Nicholson character a lot -- he seemed warm and very funny and genuinely fond of Streep and their child.  Frankly I never knew what he saw in the Streep character as she seemed like an unpleasant, unattractive, not particularly nice woman.  No wonder he began to have a roaming eye, I thought as the film progressed.  Howevever being Hollywood I figured they'd have a happy ending cooked up and so I was somewhat pleased that it ended the way it did.Then, after the credits rolled and I realized that this was indeed written by Nora Ephron it all clicked into place.  As another reviewer said, it's obviously a revenge move by Ephron and that doesn't make a good basis for a work of art.  Despite the excellent direction and the world class stars and very good supporting cast, this is mostly a waste of time.Plot summary: unlikable woman marries jerk, jerk cheats on her, woman runs to daddy, jerk comes for her and woman goes back with him, jerk cheats again, woman lives in denial for a long time, finally wakes up, throws a pie in jerk's face and goes running back to daddy.  Meanwhile their smart, clever friends quip cleverly about the affairs of other of their smart,clever friends.  They all have a lot of money, live in nice homes in DC and NYC, wear good clothes and hire women of color to clean their homes and watch the children.  My advice; skip this film and watch Streep, Nicholson, Channing et al in their other, much more worth-while films.
summary: Great cast makes this film tolerable
